gkwreg 1.0.1
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models

    Newton-Raphson Optimization for Kumaraswamy Family Distributions

    nrgkw.Rd

    Performs maximum likelihood estimation for the parameters of any distribution in the Generalized Kumaraswamy (GKw) family using a robust implementation of the Newton-Raphson algorithm. This function supports all 7 submodels: GKw, BKw, KKw, EKw, Mc (McDonald), Kw, and Beta.

    nrgkw(
  start,
  data,
  family = "gkw",
  tol = 1e-06,
  max_iter = 100L,
  verbose = FALSE,
  use_hessian = TRUE,
  step_size = 1,
  enforce_bounds = TRUE,
  min_param_val = 1e-05,
  max_param_val = 1e+05,
  get_num_hess = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    start

    A numeric vector containing initial values for parameters, with length corresponding to the selected family (see Details)

    data

    A numeric vector containing observed data. All values must be in the interval (0,1)

    family

    A character string specifying the distribution family. One of "gkw", "bkw", "kkw", "ekw", "mc", "kw", or "beta". Default: "gkw"

    tol

    Convergence tolerance. The algorithm stops when the gradient norm or parameter/likelihood changes are below this value. Default: 1e-6

    max_iter

    Maximum number of iterations. Default: 100

    verbose

    Logical flag to print detailed progress information. Default: FALSE

    use_hessian

    Logical flag to use Hessian information for parameter updates. If FALSE, the algorithm uses gradient descent instead. Default: TRUE

    step_size

    Initial step size for parameter updates. Default: 1.0

    enforce_bounds

    Logical flag to enforce parameter constraints. Default: TRUE

    min_param_val

    Minimum allowed value for parameters (except delta). Default: 1e-5

    max_param_val

    Maximum allowed value for parameters. Default: 1e5

    get_num_hess

    Logical flag to calculate numerical Hessian in addition to analytical Hessian. Default: FALSE

    Value

    A list containing the following components:

    parameters

    A numeric vector with the estimated parameters

    loglik

    The maximized log-likelihood value

    iterations

    Number of iterations performed

    converged

    Logical flag indicating whether the algorithm converged

    param_history

    Matrix of parameter values at each iteration

    loglik_history

    Vector of log-likelihood values at each iteration

    gradient

    The gradient vector at the final parameter estimates

    hessian

    The Hessian matrix at the final parameter estimates

    std_errors

    Standard errors for the estimated parameters

    aic

    Akaike Information Criterion: AIC = 2k - 2ln(L)

    bic

    Bayesian Information Criterion: BIC = k ln(n) - 2ln(L)

    n

    Sample size

    status

    Character string indicating the termination status

    z_values

    Z-statistics for parameter significance tests

    p_values

    P-values for parameter significance tests

    param_names

    Character vector of parameter names

    family

    The distribution family used in the estimation

    numeric_hessian

    Numerical approximation of the Hessian (only if get_num_hess=TRUE)

    Details

    The Generalized Kumaraswamy family includes the following distributions, all defined on (0,1):

    • GKw (Generalized Kumaraswamy): 5 parameters (α, β, γ, δ, λ)

    • BKw (Beta-Kumaraswamy): 4 parameters (α, β, γ, δ), with λ = 1 fixed

    • KKw (Kumaraswamy-Kumaraswamy): 4 parameters (α, β, δ, λ), with γ = 1 fixed

    • EKw (Exponentiated Kumaraswamy): 3 parameters (α, β, λ), with γ = 1, δ = 0 fixed

    • Mc (McDonald/Beta Power): 3 parameters (γ, δ, λ), with α = 1, β = 1 fixed

    • Kw (Kumaraswamy): 2 parameters (α, β), with γ = 1, δ = 0, λ = 1 fixed

    • Beta: 2 parameters (γ, δ), with α = 1, β = 1, λ = 1 fixed

    This function implements a sophisticated optimization procedure to find the maximum likelihood estimates with multiple fallback strategies to handle numerical challenges:

    1. Cholesky decomposition (fastest, requires positive-definite Hessian)

    2. Standard matrix solver

    3. Regularized Hessian with incremental adjustment

    4. Pseudo-inverse for highly ill-conditioned matrices

    5. Gradient descent as ultimate fallback

    The function also implements backtracking line search to ensure monotonic improvement in the log-likelihood, with random parameter perturbation as a recovery strategy when backtracking fails.

    Warning

    Convergence is not guaranteed for all datasets and initial values. It's recommended to:

    • Try different initial values if convergence fails

    • Check the gradient norm at the final solution to verify optimality

    • Examine parameter history to identify potential issues

    • Use the verbose option to get detailed progress information for troubleshooting

    References

    Kumaraswamy, P. (1980). A generalized probability density function for double-bounded random processes. Journal of Hydrology, 46(1-2), 79-88.

    Cordeiro, G. M., & de Castro, M. (2011). A new family of generalized distributions. Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, 81(7), 883-898.

    Fletcher, R. (1987). Practical Methods of Optimization. John Wiley & Sons.

    Author

    Lopes, J. E.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Generate sample data from Beta(2,5) distribution for testing
set.seed(123)
sample_data <- rbeta(200, 2, 5)

# Fit with full GKw model
gkw_result <- mle_fit(c(1.5, 4.5, 1.0, 0.0, 1.0), sample_data, family = "gkw")
gkw_result$parameters

# Fit with simpler Kumaraswamy model
kw_result <- mle_fit(c(1.5, 4.5), sample_data, family = "kw")
kw_result$parameters

# Fit with Beta model
beta_result <- mle_fit(c(2.0, 5.0), sample_data, family = "beta")
beta_result$parameters

# Compare AIC/BIC values to select the best model
data.frame(
  family = c("gkw", "kw", "beta"),
  AIC = c(gkw_result$aic, kw_result$aic, beta_result$aic),
  BIC = c(gkw_result$bic, kw_result$bic, beta_result$bic)
)
} # }
